case_vignette: A 9-year-old boy is brought to a pediatric psychologist by his mother because of poor academic performance. The patient’s mother mentions that his academic performance was excellent in kindergarten and first grade, but his second and third-grade teachers complain that he is extremely talkative, does not complete schoolwork, and frequently makes careless mistakes. They also complain that he frequently looks at other students or outside the window during the class and is often lost during the lessons. At home, he is very talkative and disorganized. When the pediatrician asks the boy his name, he replies promptly. He was born at full term by spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up-to-date on all vaccinations and has met all developmental milestones on time. A recent IQ test scored him at 95. His physical examination is completely normal. When he is asked to read from an age-appropriate children’s book, he reads it fluently and correctly.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been really talkative, not finishing my schoolwork, and often make careless mistakes.
How old are you?
I am 9 years old.
Is this a recent change in behavior, or has it been ongoing?
My academic performance dropped after first grade, and my current teachers say I've been like this since second grade.
Have your parents or teachers noticed any issues with you being hyperactive or having difficulty sitting still?
The teachers say I often look at other students or outside the window during class and seem lost during the lessons.
Do you have difficulty waiting for your turn in conversations or games?
At home, I'm very talkative and disorganized, but it's not mentioned if I have trouble waiting for my turn.
Are you currently taking any medications?
No, I'm not taking any medications.
Has there been any family history of attention disorders or learning disabilities?
There's no mention of a family history of attention disorders or learning disabilities.
Do you experience frequent mood swings or have trouble regulating your emotions?
It's not mentioned that I have mood swings or trouble regulating emotions.
Do you have trouble following instructions and completing tasks, such as chores or homework, even when you understand them?
Yes, I don't complete schoolwork and frequently make careless mistakes.
Final Diagnosis: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 9-year-old student has been exhibiting talkative and disorganized behavior, leading to a drop in academic performance since first grade. Teachers have noted that the student often looks at other students or out the window during class and seems lost during lessons. At home, the student is talkative and disorganized, and frequently does not complete schoolwork and makes careless mistakes. There is no mention of difficulty waiting for their turn or taking any medications, and no family history of attention disorders or learning disabilities. Mood swings or trouble regulating emotions are also not mentioned.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been doing poorly in school, I talk a lot, I don't finish my schoolwork, and often I make careless mistakes.
How old are you?
I am 9 years old.
Are these symptoms present at home as well as at school?
Yes, I am very talkative and disorganized at home too.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been having these issues since second grade.
Do you find it difficult to stay seated or feel restless?
My teachers say that I often look at other students or outside the window during class and get lost during the lessons.

These issues have been ongoing since second grade. The student's mother has not reported any problems with interrupting others or waiting their turn, and there are no noted sleep disturbances or family history of similar conditions.
